894f0fb10b4c2e2607f2275138222ea9 (02:16): psycose: if you want to prevent a kernel from being automatically upgraded, don't install a linux-image-386 metapacakge, install a specific kernel package, like linux-image-2.6.16-2-486 or something similar
aeb0cec193302f93ee0d4eec296530c0 (02:17): jfletcher: install java-package and use it to make a deb out of a sun-java .bin

aeb0cec193302f93ee0d4eec296530c0 (02:17): jfletcher: it's all spelled out in the how-tos, but if you refuse to read any how-tos, I'm not about to type them in line by line just because you hate reading.

894f0fb10b4c2e2607f2275138222ea9 (02:19): psycose: if you remove the linux-image-486 package, and just have a specific linux-image-2.6.xx-x-486 package installed, there is no reason a newer kernel package would be installed on you
b8dded17440c2167fa49449b16fc9fcb (02:20): Can anyone help me compiling a program

894f0fb10b4c2e2607f2275138222ea9 (02:20): psycose: well a newer version of the debian package of the same kernel version could be installed, so put the 2.6.xx-x-486 package on hold as well if you want to prevent that as well

b8dded17440c2167fa49449b16fc9fcb (02:24): stew: how do i compile a program which i have unzipped and am left with its folders and ect
894f0fb10b4c2e2607f2275138222ea9 (02:25): Sniper: that depends on the program.  it should have come with a README and/or INSTALL file with instructions
